awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports the 2019 Maine-Quebec Number Theory Conference, which will take place on October 5-6, 2019 at the University of Maine.  This is an annual conference, held at Laval University in Quebec in even years, and at the University of Maine in odd years. It provides a forum for number theorists from New England, Quebec, and beyond, to discuss their research and develop collaborations.

The conference features approximately 35 lectures addressing recent progress in different areas of number theory. The small scale of the meeting (with roughly 65 attendees) makes this a good opportunity for graduate students and young mathematicians to interact with leading researchers. This award may also provide some travel support for US-based participants to attend the 2020 meeting in Quebec. The conference website has more information, including participant lists and programs from recent years. More information can be found at https://archimede.mat.ulaval.ca/QUEBEC-MAINE/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the Maine/Quebec Number Theory Conference during the period 2019 - 2022. 

Number theory is the study of the integers and related structures. It is one of the oldest branches in mathematics, and remains a very active research discipline.  This annual conference provides a forum for researchers in number theory from New England and Quebec to meet, present and discuss their work, and initiate collaboration for future research progress. The small scale of this annual meeting makes it a good opportunity for graduate students and young mathematicians to interact with more senior researchers.

The 2019 Maine/Quebec Number Theory Conference took place on October 5-6 at the University of Maine. In all there were a record 64 lectures on an array of topics in number theory, including plenary talks by Andrew Granville (University of Montreal) and Roman Holowinsky (Ohio State University). There were at least 82 participants, including 29 graduate students and 5 undergraduates. The full program and participant list can be viewed on the conference website.

The grant provided travel and lodging for 66 conference participants in 2019 who came from outside the Orono area, as well as miscellaneous supplies.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the conference was held online in 2020 and 2021, and the grant funding was not needed.  A small portion of the grant remained, and this was used to help with the travel costs of some US-based faculty and students to attend the in-person 2022 Quebec/Maine Number Theory Conference at Laval University on October 15-16, 2022.


Last Modified: 03/01/2023
Modified by: Andrew Knightly

This grant supported the Maine/Quebec Number Theory Conference during the period 2019 - 2022.  

Number theory is the study of the integers and related structures. It is one of the oldest branches in mathematics, and remains a very active research discipline.  This annual conference provides a forum for researchers in number theory from New England and Quebec to meet, present and discuss their work, and initiate collaboration for future research progress. The small scale of this annual meeting makes it a good opportunity for graduate students and young mathematicians to interact with more senior researchers.





The 2019 Maine/Quebec Number Theory Conference took place on October 5-6 at the University of Maine. In all there were a record 64 lectures on an array of topics in number theory, including plenary talks by Andrew Granville (University of Montreal) and Roman Holowinsky (Ohio State University). There were at least 82 participants, including 29 graduate students and 5 undergraduates. The full program and participant list can be viewed on the conference website.









The grant provided travel and lodging for 66 conference participants in 2019 who came from outside the Orono area, as well as miscellaneous supplies.





Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the conference was held online in 2020 and 2021, and the grant funding was not needed.  A small portion of the grant remained, and this was used to help with the travel costs of some US-based faculty and students to attend the in-person 2022 Quebec/Maine Number Theory Conference at Laval University on October 15-16, 2022.
